intro: Oxytropis leucantha, commonly known as the white locoweed, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and compound leaves. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that are typically white or pale pink, often arranged in clusters. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes, and is adapted to arid environments. Oxytropis leucantha is also known for its ability to fix nitrogen in the soil, contributing to soil fertility.
